item.title: Report X-2025020075
item.description:
Report X-2025020075

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-31
  • City: PATERSON
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On January 31, 2025 a package was found during the PM sort that had started emitting smoke and heat. The package contained UN3480, Lithium Ion Batteries, 9. The package was immediately doused with water and an extinguisher was used to put out the flames and stop the evolution of heat, preventing more thermal runaway. The package was then isolated and is being held. FedEx Dangerous Goods Administration attempted to follow the process and report this to the NRC, however the person at the NRC, Mr. Archibald, who answered the call refused to take the report due to the incident not happening on an aircraft or American soil.

item.title: Report E-2025020013
item.description:
Report E-2025020013

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-31
  • City: EAST BRUNSWICK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5500
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: XPO-Logistics contacted ERTS regarding leaking bags containing hazardous product, ABF-004. A contractor dispatched and observed an estimated 0.5lbs of product released onto the wooden trailer floor in a 2’x2’ area as a result of dunnage due to improper loading. The contractor cleaned up the release and loose-packed the three damaged bags into one 55-gallon DF. The remaining intact freight was re-palletized and will ship onto the Consignee. Impacted cardboard and pallet pieces were containerized into two additional 55-gallon DF’s for waste disposal XPO will manage all waste generated from the response. No storm-drains, waterways, or soil were involved in this incident.

item.title: Report E-2025020008
item.description:
Report E-2025020008

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-13
  • City: KEARNY
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: At the time of loading and shipment the cargo tank appeared intact, and no leak was observed. Upon inspection at destination facility a small leak was observed from the rear door of the vehicle. No visible defects such as holes or cracks were observed. The leak appeared to be a gasket failure, but was later determined to be a more significant part of tank.

item.title: Report E-2025010433
item.description:
Report E-2025010433

Identified by scraper @ 2025-02-08T03:31:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2025-01-03
  • City: EAST BRUNSWICK
  • State: NJ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: A Duie Pyle
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 9500
  • Serious Incident Ind: Yes
  • Description: On January 03, 2025, A Duie Pyle notified Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) of a cargo release in East Brunswick, NJ. It was reported that approximately 300 gallons of UN1170 Ethanol released from a metal tote due to improper handling. The release impacted the inside of a trailer and asphalt. No storm drains or waterways were impacted. Clean Harbors was dispatched to the site to perform all onsite clean-up. Upon arrival CH reported the team inspected the tote to find it was knocked over and the lid popped off. CH reported they moved the tote upright and placed the lid back on. The team then began to work in absorbents. All clean up was completed creating eleven 55-gallon drums of impacted absorbents. All waste was taken off-site for proper disposal.
